article.title: Mapping substructure in the HST Frontier Fields cluster lenses and in cosmological simulations

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate about the HSTFF data?
choices: The HSTFF data have identified new, giant elliptical galaxies in the clusters.
The HSTFF data are of such high resolution that they reveal previously unseen, faint cluster members.
The HSTFF data have uncovered large numbers of distant quasars that lie behind the clusters.
The HSTFF data have revealed the presence of dark matter filaments connecting the clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Figure 2 convey about the cluster galaxy samples used in the analysis?
choices: The luminosity function of cluster galaxies is well-constrained by the HSTFF data.
The same luminosity cut was applied to each cluster, resulting in varying numbers of galaxies due to their redshift differences.
The majority of galaxies in each cluster are giant elliptical galaxies with luminosities greater than L*.
The luminosity function of cluster galaxies is poorly matched by the Illustris simulations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the comparison of the SHMFs derived from the Dark Matter only and Full Physics iCluster Zooms?
choices: Baryonic physics significantly alters the SHMF at all mass scales.
The inclusion of baryonic physics results in a steeper SHMF at the low-mass end.
The SHMFs are remarkably similar over the mass scales probed, indicating that baryonic effects are less significant at these masses.
The dark matter only SHMF predicts a greater abundance of subhalos at all masses.
The equation of state for dark matter.
The theoretical prediction for the subhalo mass function in the LCDM model.
The formula for calculating the gravitational lensing signal of a cluster.
The relationship between the mass and luminosity of a galaxy.
